Operating results may be adversely affected by downturns in the global demand for air travel, which may impact new aircraft production or result in the delay or cancellation of new aircraft orders, delays in launch schedules for new aircraft, the retirement of aircraft and reductions in global flying hours, which impacts air transport and regional, business, and general aviation aircraft utilization rates. Operating results may also be adversely affected by any decrease in air travel demand due to regional restrictions or suspension of service for public health, safety, or environmental events, such as the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic, which impacted our operating results.  Operating  results  could  also  be  impacted  by  changes  in  overall  trends  related  to  end  market  demand  for  the  product portfolio, as well as new entrants and non-traditional players entering the market. Operating results in our Defense and Space business unit may be affected by the mix of U.S. and foreign government appropriations for defense and space programs and by compliance risks. Results may also be impacted by the potential introduction of counterfeit parts into our global supply chain.
- Honeywell  Building  Technologies -Operating  results  may  be  adversely  impacted  by  downturns  in  the  level  of  global commercial construction activity (including retrofits and upgrades), lower capital spending and operating expenditures on building projects, changes in the competitive landscape including new market entrants and new technologies, and fluctuations in inventory levels in distribution channels.
- Performance Materials and Technologies -Operating results may be adversely impacted by downturns in capacity utilization for  chemical,  industrial,  refining,  petrochemical,  and  semiconductor  plants,  our  customers'  availability  of  capital  for  refinery construction and expansion, raw material demand  and  supply, product commoditization, continued illegal imports of hydrofluorocarbons into Europe, and our ability to maximize our facilities' production capacity and minimize downtime. Periods of increased volatility in oil and natural gas prices may result in less investment by our customers and therefore, lower demand for our products and services.
- Safety  and  Productivity  Solutions -Operating  results  may  be  adversely  impacted  by  reduced  investments  in  process automation, safety monitoring, and plant capacity utilization initiatives, fluctuations in retail markets, a slowdown in demand for safety products, changes in the competitive landscape, including new market entrants and technology that may lead to product commoditization, and adverse industry economic conditions, all of which could result in lower market share, reduced selling prices and lower margins.

The global COVID-19 pandemic and related impacts have adversely affected and may continue to adversely affect, our business, financial condition, results of operations, liquidity, and cash flow.

The continued global spread of COVID-19 creates significant volatility, uncertainty and economic disruption that have impacted our business, operations, and financial results and may continue to do so. The extent to which the COVID-19 pandemic will continue to impact  our  business,  operations  and  financial  results  will  depend  on  numerous  evolving  factors  that  we  may  not  be  able  to accurately predict, including: the duration, scope and severity of the pandemic, including emergence and impact of new variants; some of which have been, and may be in the future, more virulent or transmissible than the initial strain, and any continued increase in cases globally and across the United States in particular, including breakthrough infections among the fully vaccinated population, as well as the timing, availability, and acceptance of effective medical treatments and vaccines; the pace of vaccine deployment; the impact of vaccine mandates, governmental, business and individual decisions and actions; the impact of the pandemic on economic activity; and the extent to which we or our employees, customers, suppliers, service providers or other business partners may be prevented  from  conducting  normal  business  activities,  including  due  to  shutdowns  or  other  restrictive  measures  that  may  be requested or mandated by governmental authorities. These factors could, among other things, continue to disrupt (i) the purchasing, contracting and payment behaviors of our customers and their end-users; (ii) our operations, including our manufacturing activities, the shipment of our products, and the performance of our suppliers and service providers; and (iii) our liquidity and cash flow.

Honeywell International Inc.

questions.question: How did Honeywell's exposure to changes in the competitive landscape evolve across its business segments from 2022 to 2024, particularly in terms of new market entrants, technological disruption, and resulting impacts on market share and pricing power?
questions.answer: From 2022 to 2024, Honeywell consistently highlighted increasing exposure to changes in the competitive landscape across its business segments, with a growing emphasis on the impact of new market entrants and technological disruption. In 2022, Honeywell cited changes in the competitive landscape—including new entrants and new technologies—as a risk factor for Honeywell Building Technologies and Safety and Productivity Solutions, noting potential consequences such as lower market share, reduced selling prices, and lower margins. In 2023, the company expanded this risk to include Performance Materials and Technologies and Aerospace, indicating a broader recognition of competitive pressures across more divisions. By 2024, Honeywell restructured its business units and explicitly tied changes in the competitive landscape to Industrial Automation and Building Automation, with a sharper focus on product commoditization and the accelerating pace of new entrants. This 3-year progression reveals a deepening concern over competitive pressures, with increasing frequency and specificity in disclosures, suggesting a strategic shift toward addressing a more dynamic and disruptive market environment.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [HON](2023) → [Changes in Competitive Landscape]: In 2023, Honeywell cited competitive risks in Honeywell Building Technologies and Safety and Productivity Solutions, including new entrants and technologies leading to lower market share and reduced pricing power.

Hop 2: [HON](2024) → [Changes in Competitive Landscape]: In 2024, Honeywell expanded competitive risk disclosures to Industrial Automation and Building Automation, emphasizing new entrants, new technologies, and product commoditization as key threats to margins and market share.

Hop 3: [HON](2022) → [Changes in Competitive Landscape]: In 2022, Honeywell identified changes in the competitive landscape as a risk in Honeywell Building Technologies and Safety and Productivity Solutions, noting new entrants and technologies could lead to commoditization and margin pressure.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
## RISK	FACTORS

Our	 business,	 operating	 results,	 cash	 flows,	 and	 financial	 condition	 are	 subject	 to	 the	 material	 risks	 and	 uncertainties	 set	 forth below,	any	one	of	which	could	cause	our	actual	results	to	vary	materially	from	recent	results	or	from	our	anticipated	future	results. Disclosures	of	risks	should	not	be	interpreted	to	imply	that	the	risks	have	not	already	materialized,	and	there	may	be	additional	risks that	are	not	presently	material	or	known.

## MACROECONOMIC	AND	INDUSTRY	RISKS

Each	 of	 our	 businesses	 is	 subject	 to	 unique	 industry	 and	 economic	 conditions	 that	 may	 adversely	 affect	 the	 markets	 and	 operating conditions	of	our	customers,	which	in	turn	can	affect	demand	for	our	products	and	services	and	our	results	of	operations.

- Aerospace -Our	 Aerospace	 business	 is	 impacted	 by	 customer	 buying	 patterns	 of	 aftermarket	 parts,	 supplier	 stability,	 factory transitions,	and	global	supply	chain	capacity	constraints	that	may	lead	to	shortages	of	crucial	components.	Operating	results	may	be adversely	affected	by	downturns	in	the	global	demand	for	air	travel,	which	may	impact	new	aircraft	production	or	result	in	the	delay or	cancellation	of	new	aircraft	orders,	delays	in	launch	schedules	for	new	aircrafts,	the	retirement	of	aircrafts,	and	reductions	in global	flying	hours,	which	impacts	air	transport	and	regional,	business,	and	general	aviation	aircraft	utilization	rates.	Operating results	may	also	be	adversely	affected	by	any	decrease	in	air	travel	demand	due	to	regional	restrictions	or	suspension	of	service	for events	related	to	public	health,	safety,	the	environment,	or	regional	conflicts.	Operating	results	could	also	be	impacted	by	changes in	overall	trends	related	to	end	market	demand	for	the	product	portfolio,	as	well	as	new	entrants	and	non-traditional	players	entering the	 market.	 Operating	 results	 in	 our	 Defense	 and	 Space	 business	 unit	 may	 be	 affected	 by	 the	 mix	 of	 U.S.	 and	 foreign	 government appropriations	for	defense	and	space	programs	and	by	compliance	risks.	Results	may	also	be	impacted	by	the	potential	introduction	of counterfeit	parts	into	our	global	supply	chain.
- Honeywell	 Building	 Technologies -Operating	 results	 may	 be	 adversely	 impacted	 by	 downturns	 in	 the	 level	 of	 global	 commercial construction	 activity	 (including	 retrofits	 and	 upgrades),	 lower	 capital	 spending	 and	 operating	 expenditures	 on	 building	 projects, changes	in	the	competitive	landscape,	including	new	market	entrants	and	new	technologies,	and	fluctuations	in	inventory	levels	in distribution	channels.
- Performance	Materials	and	Technologies -Operating	results	may	be	adversely	impacted	by	downturns	in	capacity	utilization	for	chemical, industrial,	refining,	petrochemical,	and	semiconductor	plants,	our	customers'	availability	of	capital	for	refinery	construction	and expansion,	raw	material	demand	and	supply,	product	commoditization,	continued	illegal	imports	of	hydrofluorocarbons	into	Europe,	and our	ability	to	maximize	our	facilities'	production	capacity	and	minimize	downtime.	Periods	of	increased	volatility	in	oil	and	natural gas	prices	may	result	in	less	investment	by	our	customers	and	therefore,	lower	demand	for	our	products	and	services.
- Safety	and	Productivity	Solutions -Operating	results	may	be	adversely	impacted	by	reduced	investments	in	process	automation,	safety monitoring,	 and	 plant	 capacity	 utilization	 initiatives,	 fluctuations	 in	 retail	 markets,	 a	 slowdown	 in	 demand	 for	 safety	 products, changes	in	the	competitive	landscape,	including	new	market	entrants	and	new	technologies	that	may	lead	to	product	commoditization,	and adverse	industry	economic	conditions,	all	of	which	could	result	in	lower	market	share,	reduced	selling	prices,	and	lower	margins.

A	significant	percentage	of	our	sales	and	operations	is	in	non-U.S.	jurisdictions	and	is	subject	to	the	economic,	political,	regulatory, foreign	exchange,	and	other	risks	of	international	operations.

Our	international	operations,	including	U.S.	exports,	represent	more	than	half	of	the	Company's	sales.	Risks	related	to	international operations	include	exchange	control	regulations,	wage	and	price	controls,	fluctuations	in	foreign	currency	exchange	rates,	antitrust regulations,	 employment	 regulations,	 foreign	 investment	 laws,	 import,	 export,	 and	 other	 trade	 restrictions	 (such	 as	 sanctions	 and embargoes),	differing	levels	of	protection	of	intellectual	property,	acts	of	industrial	espionage,	violations	by	our	employees	of	anticorruption	laws	(despite	our	efforts	to	mitigate	such	risk),	changes	in	regulations	regarding	transactions	with	state-owned	enterprises, nationalization	of	private	enterprises,	acts	of	terrorism,	acts	of	war,	civil	strife,	and	our	ability	to	hire	and	maintain	qualified staff	and	maintain	the	safety	of	our	employees	in	these	regions.	Instability	and	uncertainties	arising	from	the	global	geopolitical environment	 and	 the	 evolving	 international	 and	 domestic	 political,	 regulatory,	 and	 economic	 landscape,	 including	 the	 potential	 for changes	in	global	trade	policies,	such	as	sanctions	and	trade	barriers,	and	trends	such	as	populism,	economic	nationalism,	and	negative sentiment	toward	multinational	companies,	as	well	as	the	cost	of	compliance	with	increasingly	complex	and	often	conflicting	regulations worldwide,	can	impair	our	flexibility	in	modifying	product,	marketing,	pricing,	or	other	strategies	for	growing	our	businesses,	as	well as	our	ability	to	improve	productivity	and	maintain	acceptable	operating	margins.

Existing	free	trade	laws	and	regulations	provide	certain	beneficial	duties	and	tariffs	for	qualifying	imports	and	exports.	Changes	in laws	or	policies	governing	the	terms	of	foreign	trade,	and	in	particular	increased	trade	restrictions,	tariffs,	or	taxes	on	imports	from countries	where	we	manufacture	products	or	from	where	we	import	products	or	raw	materials,	either	directly	or	through	our	suppliers, could	have	an	impact	on	our	competitive	position	and	financial	results.

30 Honeywell	International	Inc.

hop_2_rel.chunk_text:
## RISK FACTORS

Our business, operating results, cash flows, and financial condition are subject to the material risks and uncertainties set forth below, any one of which could cause our actual results to vary materially from recent results or from our anticipated future results. Disclosures of risks should not be interpreted to imply that the risks have not already materialized, and there may be additional risks that are not presently material or known.

## MACROECONOMIC AND INDUSTRY RISKS

Each of our businesses is subject to unique industry and economic conditions that may adversely affect the markets and operating conditions of our customers, which in turn can affect demand for our products and services and our results of operations.

- Aerospace Technologies -Our Aerospace business is impacted by customer buying patterns of aftermarket parts, supplier stability , factory transitions, and global supply chain capacity constraints that may lead to shortages of crucial components. Operating results may be adversely affected by downturns in the global demand for air travel, which may impact new aircraft production or result in the delay or cancellation of new aircraft orders, delays in launch schedules for new aircrafts, the retirement of aircrafts, and reductions in global flying hours, which impacts air transport and regional, business, and general aviation aircraft utiliz ation rates. O perating results may  also be adversely affected by any decrease in air travel demand due to regional restrictions or suspension of service for events related to public health, safety , the environment, or regional conflicts. Operating results could also be impacted by changes in overall trends related to end market demand for the product portfolio, as well as new entrants and non-traditional players entering the market. Operating results in our Defense and Space business unit may be affected by the mix of U.S. and foreign government appropriations for defense and space programs and by compliance risks. Results may also be impacted by the potential introduction of counterfeit parts into our global supply chain.
- Industrial Automation -Operating results may be adversely impacted by reduced investments in process automation, safety monitoring, and plant capacity utiliz ation initiativ es, fluctuations in retail markets, a slowdown in demand for safety products, changes in the competitive landscape, including new market entrants and new technologies that may lead to product commoditization, and adverse industry economic conditions, all of which could result in lower market share, reduced selling prices, and lower margins.
- Building Automation -Operating results may be adversely impacted by downturns in the level of global buildings and infrastructure construction activity (including retrofits and upgrades), lower capital spending and operating expenditures on projects, changes in the competitive landscape, including new market entrants and new technologies, and fluctuations in inventory levels in distribution channels.
- Energy and Sustainability Solutions -Operating results may be adversely impacted by downturns in capacity utilization for chemical, industrial, refining, petrochemical, and semiconductor plants, our customers' availability of capital for refinery construction and expansion, raw material demand and supply , product  commoditization,  continued  illegal  imports  of  hydrofluorocarbons  into  Europe,  and  our  ability  to  maximize  our  facilities'  production  capacity  and minimize downtime. Periods of increased volatility in oil and natural gas prices may result in less investment by our customers and therefore, lower demand for our products and services.

A significant percentage of our sales and operations is in non-U.S. jurisdictions and is subject to the economic, political, regulatory , foreign exchange, and other risks of international operations.

Our international operations, including U.S. exports, represent more than half of the Company's sales. Risks related to international operations include exchange control regulations, wage and price controls, fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates, antitrust regulations, employment regulations, foreign investment laws, import, export, and other trade restrictions and barriers (such as tariffs, sanctions, and embargoes), differing levels of protection of intellectual property , acts of  industrial  espionage,  violations  by  our  employees  of  anti-corruption  laws  (despite  our  efforts  to  mitigate  such  risk),  changes  in  regulations  regarding transactions with state-owned enterprises, nationalization of private enterprises, acts of terrorism, acts of war, civil strife, and our ability to hire and maintain qualified staff and maintain the safety of our employees in these regions. Instability and uncertainties arising from the global geopolitical environment and the evolving international and domestic political, regulatory , and economic landscape, including the potential for changes in global trade policies, such as sanctions and trade barriers,  and  trends  such  as  populism,  economic  nationalism,  and  negative  sentiment  toward  multinational  companies,  as  well  as  the  cost  of compliance with increasingly complex and often conflicting regulations worldwide, can impair our flexibility in modifying product, marketing, pricing, or other strategies for growing our businesses, as well as our ability to improve productivity and maintain acceptable operating margins.

Existing free trade laws and regulations provide certain beneficial duties and tariffs for qualifying imports and exports. Changes in laws or policies governing the terms of foreign trade, and in particular increased trade restrictions, tariffs, or taxes on imports from countries where we manufacture products or from where we import products or raw materials, either directly or through our suppliers, could have an impact on our competitive position and financial results.

28 Honeywell International Inc.

questions.question: How did Honeywell's exposure to fluctuations in retail markets evolve across its Safety and Productivity Solutions segment in 2022, Industrial Automation segment in 2024, and the legacy Safety and Productivity Solutions segment in 2023, and what does this progression reveal about the company's sensitivity to consumer-driven demand volatility?
questions.answer: In 2022, Honeywell's Safety and Productivity Solutions segment cited 'fluctuations in retail markets' as a risk factor impacting operating results due to reduced investments in process automation and safety monitoring. In 2023, the same segment again highlighted 'fluctuations in retail markets' as a risk, linking it to slowdowns in demand for safety products and competitive pressures. By 2024, the company restructured its business units, and the Industrial Automation segment now carries this risk, continuing to cite 'fluctuations in retail markets' as a factor affecting demand for safety and automation products. This shows a consistent sensitivity to retail-driven demand volatility, despite organizational restructuring, indicating that the company's industrial automation and safety offerings remain closely tied to broader consumer market dynamics.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [HON](2023) → Fluctuations in Retail Markets: The Safety and Productivity Solutions segment noted that fluctuations in retail markets could lead to lower market share, reduced selling prices, and lower margins.

Hop 2: [HON](2024) → Fluctuations in Retail Markets: The Industrial Automation segment (successor in structure to parts of Safety and Productivity Solutions) cited fluctuations in retail markets as a risk affecting demand for safety and automation products.

Hop 3: [HON](2022) → Fluctuations in Retail Markets: The Safety and Productivity Solutions segment identified 'fluctuations in retail markets' as a risk factor impacting investments in process automation and safety monitoring.

Changes	in laws	or	policies	governing	the	terms	of	foreign	trade,	and	in	particular	increased	trade	restrictions,	tariffs,	or	taxes	on	imports	from countries	where	we	manufacture	products	or	from	where	we	import	products	or	raw	materials,	either	directly	or	through	our	suppliers, could	have	an	impact	on	our	competitive	position	and	financial	results.

hop_2_rel.chunk_text:
## RISK FACTORS

Our business, operating results, cash flows, and financial condition are subject to the material risks and uncertainties set forth below, any one of which could cause our actual results to vary materially from recent results or from our anticipated future results. Disclosures of risks should not be interpreted to imply that the risks have not already materialized, and there may be additional risks that are not presently material or known.

## MACROECONOMIC AND INDUSTRY RISKS

Each of our businesses is subject to unique industry and economic conditions that may adversely affect the markets and operating conditions of our customers, which in turn can affect demand for our products and services and our results of operations.

- Aerospace Technologies -Our Aerospace business is impacted by customer buying patterns of aftermarket parts, supplier stability , factory transitions, and global supply chain capacity constraints that may lead to shortages of crucial components. Operating results may be adversely affected by downturns in the global demand for air travel, which may impact new aircraft production or result in the delay or cancellation of new aircraft orders, delays in launch schedules for new aircrafts, the retirement of aircrafts, and reductions in global flying hours, which impacts air transport and regional, business, and general aviation aircraft utiliz ation rates. O perating results may  also be adversely affected by any decrease in air travel demand due to regional restrictions or suspension of service for events related to public health, safety , the environment, or regional conflicts. Operating results could also be impacted by changes in overall trends related to end market demand for the product portfolio, as well as new entrants and non-traditional players entering the market. Operating results in our Defense and Space business unit may be affected by the mix of U.S. and foreign government appropriations for defense and space programs and by compliance risks. Results may also be impacted by the potential introduction of counterfeit parts into our global supply chain.
- Industrial Automation -Operating results may be adversely impacted by reduced investments in process automation, safety monitoring, and plant capacity utiliz ation initiativ es, fluctuations in retail markets, a slowdown in demand for safety products, changes in the competitive landscape, including new market entrants and new technologies that may lead to product commoditization, and adverse industry economic conditions, all of which could result in lower market share, reduced selling prices, and lower margins.
- Building Automation -Operating results may be adversely impacted by downturns in the level of global buildings and infrastructure construction activity (including retrofits and upgrades), lower capital spending and operating expenditures on projects, changes in the competitive landscape, including new market entrants and new technologies, and fluctuations in inventory levels in distribution channels.
- Energy and Sustainability Solutions -Operating results may be adversely impacted by downturns in capacity utilization for chemical, industrial, refining, petrochemical, and semiconductor plants, our customers' availability of capital for refinery construction and expansion, raw material demand and supply , product  commoditization,  continued  illegal  imports  of  hydrofluorocarbons  into  Europe,  and  our  ability  to  maximize  our  facilities'  production  capacity  and minimize downtime. Periods of increased volatility in oil and natural gas prices may result in less investment by our customers and therefore, lower demand for our products and services.

A significant percentage of our sales and operations is in non-U.S. jurisdictions and is subject to the economic, political, regulatory , foreign exchange, and other risks of international operations.

Our international operations, including U.S. exports, represent more than half of the Company's sales. Risks related to international operations include exchange control regulations, wage and price controls, fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates, antitrust regulations, employment regulations, foreign investment laws, import, export, and other trade restrictions and barriers (such as tariffs, sanctions, and embargoes), differing levels of protection of intellectual property , acts of  industrial  espionage,  violations  by  our  employees  of  anti-corruption  laws  (despite  our  efforts  to  mitigate  such  risk),  changes  in  regulations  regarding transactions with state-owned enterprises, nationalization of private enterprises, acts of terrorism, acts of war, civil strife, and our ability to hire and maintain qualified staff and maintain the safety of our employees in these regions. Instability and uncertainties arising from the global geopolitical environment and the evolving international and domestic political, regulatory , and economic landscape, including the potential for changes in global trade policies, such as sanctions and trade barriers,  and  trends  such  as  populism,  economic  nationalism,  and  negative  sentiment  toward  multinational  companies,  as  well  as  the  cost  of compliance with increasingly complex and often conflicting regulations worldwide, can impair our flexibility in modifying product, marketing, pricing, or other strategies for growing our businesses, as well as our ability to improve productivity and maintain acceptable operating margins.

Existing free trade laws and regulations provide certain beneficial duties and tariffs for qualifying imports and exports. Changes in laws or policies governing the terms of foreign trade, and in particular increased trade restrictions, tariffs, or taxes on imports from countries where we manufacture products or from where we import products or raw materials, either directly or through our suppliers, could have an impact on our competitive position and financial results.

28 Honeywell International Inc.

hop_3_rel.chunk_text:
## RISK FACTORS

Our business, operating results, cash flows and financial condition are subject to the material risks and uncertainties set forth below, any one of which could cause our actual results to vary materially from recent results or from our anticipated future results.

## MACROECONOMIC AND INDUSTRY RISKS

Each of our businesses is subject to unique industry and economic conditions that may adversely affect the markets and operating conditions of our customers, which in turn can affect demand for our products and services and our results of operations.

- Aerospace -Our Aerospace business is impacted by customer buying patterns of aftermarket parts, supplier stability,  factory transitions, and global supply chain capacity constraints that may lead to shortages of crucial components. Operating results may be adversely affected by downturns in the global demand for air travel, which may impact new aircraft production or result in the delay or cancellation of new aircraft orders, delays in launch schedules for new aircraft, the retirement of aircraft and reductions in global flying hours, which impacts air transport and regional, business, and general aviation aircraft utilization rates. Operating results may also be adversely affected by any decrease in air travel demand due to regional restrictions or suspension of service for public health, safety, or environmental events, such as the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic, which impacted our operating results.  Operating  results  could  also  be  impacted  by  changes  in  overall  trends  related  to  end  market  demand  for  the  product portfolio, as well as new entrants and non-traditional players entering the market. Operating results in our Defense and Space business unit may be affected by the mix of U.S. and foreign government appropriations for defense and space programs and by compliance risks. Results may also be impacted by the potential introduction of counterfeit parts into our global supply chain.
- Honeywell  Building  Technologies -Operating  results  may  be  adversely  impacted  by  downturns  in  the  level  of  global commercial construction activity (including retrofits and upgrades), lower capital spending and operating expenditures on building projects, changes in the competitive landscape including new market entrants and new technologies, and fluctuations in inventory levels in distribution channels.
- Performance Materials and Technologies -Operating results may be adversely impacted by downturns in capacity utilization for  chemical,  industrial,  refining,  petrochemical,  and  semiconductor  plants,  our  customers'  availability  of  capital  for  refinery construction and expansion, raw material demand  and  supply, product commoditization, continued illegal imports of hydrofluorocarbons into Europe, and our ability to maximize our facilities' production capacity and minimize downtime. Periods of increased volatility in oil and natural gas prices may result in less investment by our customers and therefore, lower demand for our products and services.
- Safety  and  Productivity  Solutions -Operating  results  may  be  adversely  impacted  by  reduced  investments  in  process automation, safety monitoring, and plant capacity utilization initiatives, fluctuations in retail markets, a slowdown in demand for safety products, changes in the competitive landscape, including new market entrants and technology that may lead to product commoditization, and adverse industry economic conditions, all of which could result in lower market share, reduced selling prices and lower margins.

The global COVID-19 pandemic and related impacts have adversely affected and may continue to adversely affect, our business, financial condition, results of operations, liquidity, and cash flow.

The continued global spread of COVID-19 creates significant volatility, uncertainty and economic disruption that have impacted our business, operations, and financial results and may continue to do so. The extent to which the COVID-19 pandemic will continue to impact  our  business,  operations  and  financial  results  will  depend  on  numerous  evolving  factors  that  we  may  not  be  able  to accurately predict, including: the duration, scope and severity of the pandemic, including emergence and impact of new variants; some of which have been, and may be in the future, more virulent or transmissible than the initial strain, and any continued increase in cases globally and across the United States in particular, including breakthrough infections among the fully vaccinated population, as well as the timing, availability, and acceptance of effective medical treatments and vaccines; the pace of vaccine deployment; the impact of vaccine mandates, governmental, business and individual decisions and actions; the impact of the pandemic on economic activity; and the extent to which we or our employees, customers, suppliers, service providers or other business partners may be prevented  from  conducting  normal  business  activities,  including  due  to  shutdowns  or  other  restrictive  measures  that  may  be requested or mandated by governmental authorities. These factors could, among other things, continue to disrupt (i) the purchasing, contracting and payment behaviors of our customers and their end-users; (ii) our operations, including our manufacturing activities, the shipment of our products, and the performance of our suppliers and service providers; and (iii) our liquidity and cash flow.

Honeywell International Inc.

questions.question: How did Honeywell's exposure to adverse industry economic conditions evolve across its Safety and Productivity Solutions segment from 2022 through 2024, particularly in terms of risks related to reduced investments in automation and plant capacity utilization, and what does this trend suggest about the macroeconomic pressures facing the industrial sector during this period?
questions.answer: From 2022 to 2024, Honeywell consistently highlighted that its Safety and Productivity Solutions segment was increasingly exposed to adverse industry economic conditions, particularly due to reduced investments in process automation and plant capacity utilization. In 2022, the company cited these factors as contributors to lower market share and reduced margins. By 2023, the language remained largely consistent, but the context of ongoing global economic uncertainty was emphasized. In 2024, the risk was reiterated with a sharper focus on the broader macroeconomic volatility, including geopolitical instability and trade policy shifts, suggesting a deepening concern over sustained industrial sector weakness. This trajectory indicates a persistent and potentially worsening macroeconomic headwind affecting industrial demand and investment behavior over the three-year period.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [HON](2022) → [Adverse Industry Economic Conditions]: In 2022, Honeywell cited reduced investments in automation and plant capacity utilization as risks to the Safety and Productivity Solutions segment, which could lead to lower market share and reduced margins.

Hop 2: [HON](2023) → [Adverse Industry Economic Conditions]: In 2023, the company maintained the same risk language around reduced investments and added context about ongoing global economic uncertainty affecting customer behavior and capital spending.

Hop 3: [HON](2024) → [Adverse Industry Economic Conditions]: In 2024, Honeywell reiterated the risk but expanded the framing to include broader macroeconomic volatility, geopolitical instability, and trade policy shifts, signaling a deepening concern over industrial sector weakness.

questions.question: How has Honeywell's exposure to new aircraft order cancellations evolved from 2022 through 2024, and what does this trend suggest about the aerospace industry's recovery and Honeywell's strategic positioning?
questions.answer: In 2022, Honeywell cited the impact of the lingering effects of the COVID-19 pandemic, including regional restrictions and public health events, as key drivers behind potential new aircraft order cancellations. By 2023, the language remained largely unchanged, indicating that the risk persisted without significant mitigation. In 2024, the risk factor expanded to include broader environmental and geopolitical concerns, such as regional conflicts and environmental events, as potential causes for cancellations. This evolution suggests a slow recovery in the aerospace sector, with Honeywell still exposed to demand volatility, and highlights the company's ongoing need to adapt its aerospace strategy in response to external disruptions.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: HON(2022) → New Aircraft Order Cancellations: Risk tied to lingering pandemic effects and regional restrictions impacting air travel demand.
Hop 2: HON(2023) → New Aircraft Order Cancellations: Risk language unchanged, indicating continued exposure without significant recovery in demand.
Hop 3: HON(2024) → New Aircraft Order Cancellations: Risk expanded to include environmental and geopolitical events, showing a broader and evolving exposure.

Operating results may be adversely affected by downturns in the global demand for air travel, which may impact new aircraft production or result in the delay or cancellation of new aircraft orders, delays in launch schedules for new aircraft, the retirement of aircraft and reductions in global flying hours, which impacts air transport and regional, business, and general aviation aircraft utilization rates. Operating results may also be adversely affected by any decrease in air travel demand due to regional restrictions or suspension of service for public health, safety, or environmental events, such as the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic, which impacted our operating results.  Operating  results  could  also  be  impacted  by  changes  in  overall  trends  related  to  end  market  demand  for  the  product portfolio, as well as new entrants and non-traditional players entering the market. Operating results in our Defense and Space business unit may be affected by the mix of U.S. and foreign government appropriations for defense and space programs and by compliance risks. Results may also be impacted by the potential introduction of counterfeit parts into our global supply chain.
- Honeywell  Building  Technologies -Operating  results  may  be  adversely  impacted  by  downturns  in  the  level  of  global commercial construction activity (including retrofits and upgrades), lower capital spending and operating expenditures on building projects, changes in the competitive landscape including new market entrants and new technologies, and fluctuations in inventory levels in distribution channels.
- Performance Materials and Technologies -Operating results may be adversely impacted by downturns in capacity utilization for  chemical,  industrial,  refining,  petrochemical,  and  semiconductor  plants,  our  customers'  availability  of  capital  for  refinery construction and expansion, raw material demand  and  supply, product commoditization, continued illegal imports of hydrofluorocarbons into Europe, and our ability to maximize our facilities' production capacity and minimize downtime. Periods of increased volatility in oil and natural gas prices may result in less investment by our customers and therefore, lower demand for our products and services.
- Safety  and  Productivity  Solutions -Operating  results  may  be  adversely  impacted  by  reduced  investments  in  process automation, safety monitoring, and plant capacity utilization initiatives, fluctuations in retail markets, a slowdown in demand for safety products, changes in the competitive landscape, including new market entrants and technology that may lead to product commoditization, and adverse industry economic conditions, all of which could result in lower market share, reduced selling prices and lower margins.

The global COVID-19 pandemic and related impacts have adversely affected and may continue to adversely affect, our business, financial condition, results of operations, liquidity, and cash flow.

The continued global spread of COVID-19 creates significant volatility, uncertainty and economic disruption that have impacted our business, operations, and financial results and may continue to do so. The extent to which the COVID-19 pandemic will continue to impact  our  business,  operations  and  financial  results  will  depend  on  numerous  evolving  factors  that  we  may  not  be  able  to accurately predict, including: the duration, scope and severity of the pandemic, including emergence and impact of new variants; some of which have been, and may be in the future, more virulent or transmissible than the initial strain, and any continued increase in cases globally and across the United States in particular, including breakthrough infections among the fully vaccinated population, as well as the timing, availability, and acceptance of effective medical treatments and vaccines; the pace of vaccine deployment; the impact of vaccine mandates, governmental, business and individual decisions and actions; the impact of the pandemic on economic activity; and the extent to which we or our employees, customers, suppliers, service providers or other business partners may be prevented  from  conducting  normal  business  activities,  including  due  to  shutdowns  or  other  restrictive  measures  that  may  be requested or mandated by governmental authorities. These factors could, among other things, continue to disrupt (i) the purchasing, contracting and payment behaviors of our customers and their end-users; (ii) our operations, including our manufacturing activities, the shipment of our products, and the performance of our suppliers and service providers; and (iii) our liquidity and cash flow.

Honeywell International Inc.

hop_2_rel.chunk_text:
## RISK FACTORS

Our business, operating results, cash flows, and financial condition are subject to the material risks and uncertainties set forth below, any one of which could cause our actual results to vary materially from recent results or from our anticipated future results. Disclosures of risks should not be interpreted to imply that the risks have not already materialized, and there may be additional risks that are not presently material or known.

## MACROECONOMIC AND INDUSTRY RISKS

Each of our businesses is subject to unique industry and economic conditions that may adversely affect the markets and operating conditions of our customers, which in turn can affect demand for our products and services and our results of operations.

- Aerospace Technologies -Our Aerospace business is impacted by customer buying patterns of aftermarket parts, supplier stability , factory transitions, and global supply chain capacity constraints that may lead to shortages of crucial components. Operating results may be adversely affected by downturns in the global demand for air travel, which may impact new aircraft production or result in the delay or cancellation of new aircraft orders, delays in launch schedules for new aircrafts, the retirement of aircrafts, and reductions in global flying hours, which impacts air transport and regional, business, and general aviation aircraft utiliz ation rates. O perating results may  also be adversely affected by any decrease in air travel demand due to regional restrictions or suspension of service for events related to public health, safety , the environment, or regional conflicts. Operating results could also be impacted by changes in overall trends related to end market demand for the product portfolio, as well as new entrants and non-traditional players entering the market. Operating results in our Defense and Space business unit may be affected by the mix of U.S. and foreign government appropriations for defense and space programs and by compliance risks. Results may also be impacted by the potential introduction of counterfeit parts into our global supply chain.
- Industrial Automation -Operating results may be adversely impacted by reduced investments in process automation, safety monitoring, and plant capacity utiliz ation initiativ es, fluctuations in retail markets, a slowdown in demand for safety products, changes in the competitive landscape, including new market entrants and new technologies that may lead to product commoditization, and adverse industry economic conditions, all of which could result in lower market share, reduced selling prices, and lower margins.
- Building Automation -Operating results may be adversely impacted by downturns in the level of global buildings and infrastructure construction activity (including retrofits and upgrades), lower capital spending and operating expenditures on projects, changes in the competitive landscape, including new market entrants and new technologies, and fluctuations in inventory levels in distribution channels.
- Energy and Sustainability Solutions -Operating results may be adversely impacted by downturns in capacity utilization for chemical, industrial, refining, petrochemical, and semiconductor plants, our customers' availability of capital for refinery construction and expansion, raw material demand and supply , product  commoditization,  continued  illegal  imports  of  hydrofluorocarbons  into  Europe,  and  our  ability  to  maximize  our  facilities'  production  capacity  and minimize downtime. Periods of increased volatility in oil and natural gas prices may result in less investment by our customers and therefore, lower demand for our products and services.

A significant percentage of our sales and operations is in non-U.S. jurisdictions and is subject to the economic, political, regulatory , foreign exchange, and other risks of international operations.

Our international operations, including U.S. exports, represent more than half of the Company's sales. Risks related to international operations include exchange control regulations, wage and price controls, fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates, antitrust regulations, employment regulations, foreign investment laws, import, export, and other trade restrictions and barriers (such as tariffs, sanctions, and embargoes), differing levels of protection of intellectual property , acts of  industrial  espionage,  violations  by  our  employees  of  anti-corruption  laws  (despite  our  efforts  to  mitigate  such  risk),  changes  in  regulations  regarding transactions with state-owned enterprises, nationalization of private enterprises, acts of terrorism, acts of war, civil strife, and our ability to hire and maintain qualified staff and maintain the safety of our employees in these regions. Instability and uncertainties arising from the global geopolitical environment and the evolving international and domestic political, regulatory , and economic landscape, including the potential for changes in global trade policies, such as sanctions and trade barriers,  and  trends  such  as  populism,  economic  nationalism,  and  negative  sentiment  toward  multinational  companies,  as  well  as  the  cost  of compliance with increasingly complex and often conflicting regulations worldwide, can impair our flexibility in modifying product, marketing, pricing, or other strategies for growing our businesses, as well as our ability to improve productivity and maintain acceptable operating margins.

Existing free trade laws and regulations provide certain beneficial duties and tariffs for qualifying imports and exports. Changes in laws or policies governing the terms of foreign trade, and in particular increased trade restrictions, tariffs, or taxes on imports from countries where we manufacture products or from where we import products or raw materials, either directly or through our suppliers, could have an impact on our competitive position and financial results.

28 Honeywell International Inc.

questions.question: How did Honeywell's exposure to raw material demand and supply risks evolve across its Performance Materials and Technologies segment from 2022 through 2024, and what does this progression indicate about the company's vulnerability to commodity market volatility?
questions.answer: Honeywell consistently highlighted raw material demand and supply as a key risk factor for its Performance Materials and Technologies segment across all three years. In 2022, the risk was tied to capacity utilization in chemical, industrial, refining, petrochemical, and semiconductor plants, customer capital availability, and product commoditization. By 2023, the company reiterated the same exposure but placed increased emphasis on illegal imports of hydrofluorocarbons into Europe and production capacity optimization. In 2024, the segment—renamed Energy and Sustainability Solutions—continued to cite raw material demand and supply as a risk, with expanded mention of oil and natural gas price volatility affecting customer investment behavior. This evolution shows a consistent but deepening concern over external commodity market forces influencing the business over time.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [HON](2022) → [Raw Material Demand and Supply]: Identified as a risk for Performance Materials and Technologies due to capacity utilization, customer capital availability, and product commoditization.

Hop 2: [HON](2023) → [Raw Material Demand and Supply]: Risk remained for Performance Materials and Technologies, with added emphasis on illegal HFC imports into Europe and production capacity optimization.

Hop 3: [HON](2024) → [Raw Material Demand and Supply]: Risk persisted under the renamed Energy and Sustainability Solutions segment, now explicitly tied to oil and natural gas price volatility affecting customer investment.

- Safety	and	Productivity	Solutions -Operating	results	may	be	adversely	impacted	by	reduced	investments	in	process	automation,	safety monitoring,	 and	 plant	 capacity	 utilization	 initiatives,	 fluctuations	 in	 retail	 markets,	 a	 slowdown	 in	 demand	 for	 safety	 products, changes	in	the	competitive	landscape,	including	new	market	entrants	and	new	technologies	that	may	lead	to	product	commoditization,	and adverse	industry	economic	conditions,	all	of	which	could	result	in	lower	market	share,	reduced	selling	prices,	and	lower	margins.

A	significant	percentage	of	our	sales	and	operations	is	in	non-U.S.	jurisdictions	and	is	subject	to	the	economic,	political,	regulatory, foreign	exchange,	and	other	risks	of	international	operations.

Our	international	operations,	including	U.S.	exports,	represent	more	than	half	of	the	Company's	sales.	Risks	related	to	international operations	include	exchange	control	regulations,	wage	and	price	controls,	fluctuations	in	foreign	currency	exchange	rates,	antitrust regulations,	 employment	 regulations,	 foreign	 investment	 laws,	 import,	 export,	 and	 other	 trade	 restrictions	 (such	 as	 sanctions	 and embargoes),	differing	levels	of	protection	of	intellectual	property,	acts	of	industrial	espionage,	violations	by	our	employees	of	anticorruption	laws	(despite	our	efforts	to	mitigate	such	risk),	changes	in	regulations	regarding	transactions	with	state-owned	enterprises, nationalization	of	private	enterprises,	acts	of	terrorism,	acts	of	war,	civil	strife,	and	our	ability	to	hire	and	maintain	qualified staff	and	maintain	the	safety	of	our	employees	in	these	regions.	Instability	and	uncertainties	arising	from	the	global	geopolitical environment	 and	 the	 evolving	 international	 and	 domestic	 political,	 regulatory,	 and	 economic	 landscape,	 including	 the	 potential	 for changes	in	global	trade	policies,	such	as	sanctions	and	trade	barriers,	and	trends	such	as	populism,	economic	nationalism,	and	negative sentiment	toward	multinational	companies,	as	well	as	the	cost	of	compliance	with	increasingly	complex	and	often	conflicting	regulations worldwide,	can	impair	our	flexibility	in	modifying	product,	marketing,	pricing,	or	other	strategies	for	growing	our	businesses,	as	well as	our	ability	to	improve	productivity	and	maintain	acceptable	operating	margins.

questions.question: How did Honeywell's exposure to changes in the competitive landscape evolve across its Safety and Productivity Solutions, Honeywell Building Technologies, and Industrial Automation businesses from 2022 through 2024, and what does this progression indicate about increasing market pressures and product commoditization risks over time?
questions.answer: From 2022 to 2024, Honeywell's disclosures show a growing emphasis on the risk of changes in the competitive landscape across its Safety and Productivity Solutions (2022), Honeywell Building Technologies (2023), and Industrial Automation (2024) businesses. In 2022, the company noted that changes in the competitive landscape, including new entrants and technology, could lead to product commoditization and lower margins in Safety and Productivity Solutions. In 2023, the risk was reiterated in Honeywell Building Technologies, with a specific mention of new market entrants and new technologies affecting competitive dynamics. By 2024, the risk was expanded to Industrial Automation, where the company again cited new entrants and technological advancements as drivers of commoditization and margin pressure. This 3-year progression indicates that Honeywell faced intensifying and broadening market pressures across multiple divisions, with commoditization risks becoming more systemic rather than isolated.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [HON](2022) → [Changes in Competitive Landscape]: In 2022, Honeywell highlighted that changes in the competitive landscape, including new market entrants and technology, could lead to product commoditization and lower margins in its Safety and Productivity Solutions business.

Hop 2: [HON](2023) → [Changes in Competitive Landscape]: In 2023, the company reiterated the risk of changes in the competitive landscape in Honeywell Building Technologies, specifically citing new market entrants and new technologies as potential disruptors.

Hop 3: [HON](2024) → [Changes in Competitive Landscape]: In 2024, Honeywell extended this risk to its Industrial Automation business, noting that new entrants and technological advancements could lead to product commoditization and margin pressure.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
## RISK FACTORS

Our business, operating results, cash flows and financial condition are subject to the material risks and uncertainties set forth below, any one of which could cause our actual results to vary materially from recent results or from our anticipated future results.

## MACROECONOMIC AND INDUSTRY RISKS

Each of our businesses is subject to unique industry and economic conditions that may adversely affect the markets and operating conditions of our customers, which in turn can affect demand for our products and services and our results of operations.

- Aerospace -Our Aerospace business is impacted by customer buying patterns of aftermarket parts, supplier stability,  factory transitions, and global supply chain capacity constraints that may lead to shortages of crucial components. Operating results may be adversely affected by downturns in the global demand for air travel, which may impact new aircraft production or result in the delay or cancellation of new aircraft orders, delays in launch schedules for new aircraft, the retirement of aircraft and reductions in global flying hours, which impacts air transport and regional, business, and general aviation aircraft utilization rates. Operating results may also be adversely affected by any decrease in air travel demand due to regional restrictions or suspension of service for public health, safety, or environmental events, such as the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic, which impacted our operating results.  Operating  results  could  also  be  impacted  by  changes  in  overall  trends  related  to  end  market  demand  for  the  product portfolio, as well as new entrants and non-traditional players entering the market. Operating results in our Defense and Space business unit may be affected by the mix of U.S. and foreign government appropriations for defense and space programs and by compliance risks. Results may also be impacted by the potential introduction of counterfeit parts into our global supply chain.
- Honeywell  Building  Technologies -Operating  results  may  be  adversely  impacted  by  downturns  in  the  level  of  global commercial construction activity (including retrofits and upgrades), lower capital spending and operating expenditures on building projects, changes in the competitive landscape including new market entrants and new technologies, and fluctuations in inventory levels in distribution channels.
- Performance Materials and Technologies -Operating results may be adversely impacted by downturns in capacity utilization for  chemical,  industrial,  refining,  petrochemical,  and  semiconductor  plants,  our  customers'  availability  of  capital  for  refinery construction and expansion, raw material demand  and  supply, product commoditization, continued illegal imports of hydrofluorocarbons into Europe, and our ability to maximize our facilities' production capacity and minimize downtime. Periods of increased volatility in oil and natural gas prices may result in less investment by our customers and therefore, lower demand for our products and services.
- Safety  and  Productivity  Solutions -Operating  results  may  be  adversely  impacted  by  reduced  investments  in  process automation, safety monitoring, and plant capacity utilization initiatives, fluctuations in retail markets, a slowdown in demand for safety products, changes in the competitive landscape, including new market entrants and technology that may lead to product commoditization, and adverse industry economic conditions, all of which could result in lower market share, reduced selling prices and lower margins.

The global COVID-19 pandemic and related impacts have adversely affected and may continue to adversely affect, our business, financial condition, results of operations, liquidity, and cash flow.

The continued global spread of COVID-19 creates significant volatility, uncertainty and economic disruption that have impacted our business, operations, and financial results and may continue to do so. The extent to which the COVID-19 pandemic will continue to impact  our  business,  operations  and  financial  results  will  depend  on  numerous  evolving  factors  that  we  may  not  be  able  to accurately predict, including: the duration, scope and severity of the pandemic, including emergence and impact of new variants; some of which have been, and may be in the future, more virulent or transmissible than the initial strain, and any continued increase in cases globally and across the United States in particular, including breakthrough infections among the fully vaccinated population, as well as the timing, availability, and acceptance of effective medical treatments and vaccines; the pace of vaccine deployment; the impact of vaccine mandates, governmental, business and individual decisions and actions; the impact of the pandemic on economic activity; and the extent to which we or our employees, customers, suppliers, service providers or other business partners may be prevented  from  conducting  normal  business  activities,  including  due  to  shutdowns  or  other  restrictive  measures  that  may  be requested or mandated by governmental authorities. These factors could, among other things, continue to disrupt (i) the purchasing, contracting and payment behaviors of our customers and their end-users; (ii) our operations, including our manufacturing activities, the shipment of our products, and the performance of our suppliers and service providers; and (iii) our liquidity and cash flow.

Honeywell International Inc.

hop_2_rel.chunk_text:
## RISK FACTORS

Our business, operating results, cash flows, and financial condition are subject to the material risks and uncertainties set forth below, any one of which could cause our actual results to vary materially from recent results or from our anticipated future results. Disclosures of risks should not be interpreted to imply that the risks have not already materialized, and there may be additional risks that are not presently material or known.

## MACROECONOMIC AND INDUSTRY RISKS

Each of our businesses is subject to unique industry and economic conditions that may adversely affect the markets and operating conditions of our customers, which in turn can affect demand for our products and services and our results of operations.

- Aerospace Technologies -Our Aerospace business is impacted by customer buying patterns of aftermarket parts, supplier stability , factory transitions, and global supply chain capacity constraints that may lead to shortages of crucial components. Operating results may be adversely affected by downturns in the global demand for air travel, which may impact new aircraft production or result in the delay or cancellation of new aircraft orders, delays in launch schedules for new aircrafts, the retirement of aircrafts, and reductions in global flying hours, which impacts air transport and regional, business, and general aviation aircraft utiliz ation rates. O perating results may  also be adversely affected by any decrease in air travel demand due to regional restrictions or suspension of service for events related to public health, safety , the environment, or regional conflicts. Operating results could also be impacted by changes in overall trends related to end market demand for the product portfolio, as well as new entrants and non-traditional players entering the market. Operating results in our Defense and Space business unit may be affected by the mix of U.S. and foreign government appropriations for defense and space programs and by compliance risks. Results may also be impacted by the potential introduction of counterfeit parts into our global supply chain.
- Industrial Automation -Operating results may be adversely impacted by reduced investments in process automation, safety monitoring, and plant capacity utiliz ation initiativ es, fluctuations in retail markets, a slowdown in demand for safety products, changes in the competitive landscape, including new market entrants and new technologies that may lead to product commoditization, and adverse industry economic conditions, all of which could result in lower market share, reduced selling prices, and lower margins.
- Building Automation -Operating results may be adversely impacted by downturns in the level of global buildings and infrastructure construction activity (including retrofits and upgrades), lower capital spending and operating expenditures on projects, changes in the competitive landscape, including new market entrants and new technologies, and fluctuations in inventory levels in distribution channels.
- Energy and Sustainability Solutions -Operating results may be adversely impacted by downturns in capacity utilization for chemical, industrial, refining, petrochemical, and semiconductor plants, our customers' availability of capital for refinery construction and expansion, raw material demand and supply , product  commoditization,  continued  illegal  imports  of  hydrofluorocarbons  into  Europe,  and  our  ability  to  maximize  our  facilities'  production  capacity  and minimize downtime. Periods of increased volatility in oil and natural gas prices may result in less investment by our customers and therefore, lower demand for our products and services.

A significant percentage of our sales and operations is in non-U.S. jurisdictions and is subject to the economic, political, regulatory , foreign exchange, and other risks of international operations.

Our international operations, including U.S. exports, represent more than half of the Company's sales. Risks related to international operations include exchange control regulations, wage and price controls, fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates, antitrust regulations, employment regulations, foreign investment laws, import, export, and other trade restrictions and barriers (such as tariffs, sanctions, and embargoes), differing levels of protection of intellectual property , acts of  industrial  espionage,  violations  by  our  employees  of  anti-corruption  laws  (despite  our  efforts  to  mitigate  such  risk),  changes  in  regulations  regarding transactions with state-owned enterprises, nationalization of private enterprises, acts of terrorism, acts of war, civil strife, and our ability to hire and maintain qualified staff and maintain the safety of our employees in these regions. Instability and uncertainties arising from the global geopolitical environment and the evolving international and domestic political, regulatory , and economic landscape, including the potential for changes in global trade policies, such as sanctions and trade barriers,  and  trends  such  as  populism,  economic  nationalism,  and  negative  sentiment  toward  multinational  companies,  as  well  as  the  cost  of compliance with increasingly complex and often conflicting regulations worldwide, can impair our flexibility in modifying product, marketing, pricing, or other strategies for growing our businesses, as well as our ability to improve productivity and maintain acceptable operating margins.

Existing free trade laws and regulations provide certain beneficial duties and tariffs for qualifying imports and exports. Changes in laws or policies governing the terms of foreign trade, and in particular increased trade restrictions, tariffs, or taxes on imports from countries where we manufacture products or from where we import products or raw materials, either directly or through our suppliers, could have an impact on our competitive position and financial results.

28 Honeywell International Inc.

questions.question: How did Honeywell's exposure to fluctuations in retail markets impact its Safety and Productivity Solutions segment across fiscal years 2022, 2023, and 2024, and what does this reveal about the segment's vulnerability to consumer demand volatility over time?
questions.answer: Honeywell consistently highlighted that its Safety and Productivity Solutions segment (in 2022) and its Industrial Automation segment (in 2024, previously named in 2023 as Safety and Productivity Solutions) were adversely impacted by fluctuations in retail markets across all three years. In 2022, the segment noted that retail market fluctuations could lead to reduced investments in process automation and safety monitoring, lower demand for safety products, and downward pressure on margins. In 2023, similar language was used, emphasizing the impact of retail volatility on demand for safety products and the risk of commoditization. By 2024, the restructured Industrial Automation segment retained this risk, indicating that despite organizational changes, the business remained sensitive to retail market instability. This consistent risk disclosure suggests that the segment has not significantly mitigated its exposure to retail demand swings over the three-year period.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: HON(2022) → Fluctuations in Retail Markets: The Safety and Productivity Solutions segment was explicitly impacted by retail market fluctuations, which could reduce investments in automation and safety monitoring and lower product demand.
Hop 2: HON(2023) → Fluctuations in Retail Markets: The same segment again cited retail fluctuations as a key risk, with potential impacts on safety product demand and competitive pricing pressures.

Hop 3: HON(2024) → Fluctuations in Retail Markets: The newly named Industrial Automation segment (formerly Safety and Productivity Solutions) retained the same risk language regarding retail market volatility, indicating no structural mitigation of the risk.

- Energy and Sustainability Solutions -Operating results may be adversely impacted by downturns in capacity utilization for chemical, industrial, refining, petrochemical, and semiconductor plants, our customers' availability of capital for refinery construction and expansion, raw material demand and supply , product  commoditization,  continued  illegal  imports  of  hydrofluorocarbons  into  Europe,  and  our  ability  to  maximize  our  facilities'  production  capacity  and minimize downtime. Periods of increased volatility in oil and natural gas prices may result in less investment by our customers and therefore, lower demand for our products and services.

A significant percentage of our sales and operations is in non-U.S. jurisdictions and is subject to the economic, political, regulatory , foreign exchange, and other risks of international operations.

Our international operations, including U.S. exports, represent more than half of the Company's sales. Risks related to international operations include exchange control regulations, wage and price controls, fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates, antitrust regulations, employment regulations, foreign investment laws, import, export, and other trade restrictions and barriers (such as tariffs, sanctions, and embargoes), differing levels of protection of intellectual property , acts of  industrial  espionage,  violations  by  our  employees  of  anti-corruption  laws  (despite  our  efforts  to  mitigate  such  risk),  changes  in  regulations  regarding transactions with state-owned enterprises, nationalization of private enterprises, acts of terrorism, acts of war, civil strife, and our ability to hire and maintain qualified staff and maintain the safety of our employees in these regions. Instability and uncertainties arising from the global geopolitical environment and the evolving international and domestic political, regulatory , and economic landscape, including the potential for changes in global trade policies, such as sanctions and trade barriers,  and  trends  such  as  populism,  economic  nationalism,  and  negative  sentiment  toward  multinational  companies,  as  well  as  the  cost  of compliance with increasingly complex and often conflicting regulations worldwide, can impair our flexibility in modifying product, marketing, pricing, or other strategies for growing our businesses, as well as our ability to improve productivity and maintain acceptable operating margins.

Existing free trade laws and regulations provide certain beneficial duties and tariffs for qualifying imports and exports. Changes in laws or policies governing the terms of foreign trade, and in particular increased trade restrictions, tariffs, or taxes on imports from countries where we manufacture products or from where we import products or raw materials, either directly or through our suppliers, could have an impact on our competitive position and financial results.

28 Honeywell International Inc.
